sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 47056/11) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by two Russian nationals, Ms Marina Stanislavovna Panyushkina (“the first applicant”) and Mr Vyacheslav Aleksandrovich Panyushkin (“the second applicant”), on 20 May 2011.
2.  The applicants were represented by Ms O.P. Tseytlina, a lawyer practising in St Petersburg. The Russian Government (“the Government”) were represented initially by Mr G. Matyushkin, the Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights, and then by his successor in that office, Mr M. Galperin.
3.  The applicants alleged that their right to respect for their home had been violated.
4.  On 19 September 2016 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicants’ right to respect for their home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicants were born in 1971 and 1997 respectively and live in St Petersburg. They are a single mother and her son.
A.  Background to the case
6.  In 1995 the first applicant and her mother left Uzbekistan for Russia and settled in St Petersburg. They were granted the status of “forced migrants” for an initial period of five years. In 1997 the second applicant was born.
7.  In 1998 the Federal Migration Service (“the FMS”) provided the applicants and the first applicant’s mother with a room in a three-room flat. A social tenancy agreement was concluded with the first applicant’s mother.
8.  In October 2000 the FMS extended the forced migrant status of the first applicant and her mother until 2 June 2001.
9.  In July 2001 the second applicant was registered as living in the room.
B.  Proceedings against the FMS concerning the status of forced migrant
10.  On 8 November 2001 the FMS deprived the first applicant of her status as a forced migrant on the grounds that she had not applied in due time for it to be extended. According to the first applicant, she was not informed of that decision until 2003.
11.  In 2002 the first applicant was excluded from the social tenancy agreement owing to the fact that she had lost her forced migrant status.
12.  On 17 February and 16 April 2003 the first applicant applied to the FMS with a request to re-establish her status as a forced migrant.
13.  On 20 February and 8 May 2003 respectively the FMS upheld its decision of 8 November 2001 and dismissed the first applicant’s request.
14.  In February 2009 the first applicant’s mother died.
15.  In July 2009 the FMS ordered the applicants to vacate the room. The applicants did not vacate the room and continued to live in it.
16.  In December 2009 the applicants were placed on the waiting list for social housing.
17.  On 19 January 2010 the applicant applied to the FMS with a new request to re-establish her forced migrant status.
18.  On 25 January 2010 the FMS upheld its decision of 8 November 2001. The first applicant decided to challenge that decision in court.
19.  On 3 November 2010 the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg held that the decision of 25 January 2010 had been unlawful and had to be set aside. In particular, the court held that the first applicant had had valid reasons for missing the deadline for applying for an extension of her forced migrant status. The court ordered the FMS to extend the first applicant’s migrant status.
20.  On 25 January 2011 the St Petersburg City Court quashed the decision of 3 November 2010 and dismissed the first applicant’s complaint against the decision of the FMS of 25 January 2010. The court held, in particular, that between 2003 and 2010 the first applicant had not tried to contest the refusals of the FMS of 8 November 2001, 20 February and 8 May 2003 to re-establish her forced migrant status, which showed that she had lost interest in having that status. In her complaint the first applicant had contested the decision of 25 January 2010 and therefore, it was irrelevant whether she had had valid reasons for missing the deadline for applying for an extension of her status. The court held, that the decision of 25 January 2010 had been based on Section 5 (4), of the Federal Law on Forced Migrants, which provided that the extension of the status of forced migrants could be granted only at their request (see Relevant domestic law below). Therefore, there were no grounds for declaring that decision unlawful.
C.  Eviction proceedings
21.  In 2011 the FMS brought court proceedings against the applicants, seeking their eviction from the room.
22.  The local authorities objected to the eviction, because the room was the only dwelling available to the second applicant.
23.  The applicants submitted that their eviction would be in breach of Article 8 of the Convention, since it was not necessary in a democratic society. The room in question was their only dwelling. They had been on the waiting list for social housing since 2009. The first applicant was a single mother whose income was insufficient for buying a flat.
24.  On 15 May 2012 the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg ordered the applicants’ eviction from their room, without providing any alternative accommodation. In particular, the District Court held as follows:
“... Panyushkina M.S. [the first applicant] lost her forced migrant status in 2001, her minor son has never had such a status, and therefore the court comes to the conclusion that the respondents unlawfully occupy the disputed housing and should be evicted without the provision of any alternative accommodation ...”
25.  The applicants lodged an appeal against the eviction order, submitting that their eviction was disproportionate since the court had not taken their arguments into account.
26.  On 4 October 2012 the St Petersburg City Court upheld the eviction order. In particular, the City Court held as follows:
 “... It is impossible to take into account the arguments submitted by Panyushkina M.S. [the first applicant] in her grounds of appeal, whereby the eviction from the disputed housing without the provision of any alternative accommodation is a violation of their [the applicants’] housing rights, since they do not have any other housing. The housing stock aimed at providing forced migrants with temporary housing is for a strictly designated use – the provision with housing of individuals who have been legally acknowledged to be forced migrants and their family members; the loss or deprivation of the status of forced migrant implies the loss of the right to live in the housing, termination of the social tenancy agreement and the obligation to vacate the occupied accommodation ...”
27.  The applicants did not lodge a cassation appeal against the above decisions.
28.  On 22 November 2012 the bailiff instituted enforcement proceedings with regard to the eviction order. The applicants were given five days to comply voluntarily with the judgment of 15 May 2012.
D.  Provision of alternative accommodation
29.  On 13 May 2013 the first applicant asked the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg to provide her with alternative accommodation.
30.  On 12 August 2013 the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg concluded an agreement with the first applicant for use of social accommodation free of charge for a period of one year. The Government submitted that it had been open to the applicants to apply for an extension of that agreement. However, they had not asked for the agreement to be extended after the expiry of the initial period. The applicants submitted that it had not been possible to ask for any extension of the agreement.
31.  On 12 September 2013 the applicants vacated the disputed room in compliance with the eviction order of 15 May 2012.
32.  On 11 March 2015 the enforcement proceedings were terminated on the grounds that the applicants had voluntarily vacated the room.
33.  Since 15 March 2016 the second applicant has been registered as living in the flat belonging to his father and his paternal grandmother.
34.  The first applicant was currently renting for her and her son a room in a shared apartment at her own expense. Her landlord had not registered her as living at the address of the rented room. She submitted that she had asked her former husband to register the second applicant as living in his flat by necessity, because the absence of registration had subjected him to everyday difficulties. However, de facto the second applicant had continued to live with the first applicant.
35.  According to the information provided by the Government, in 2016 the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg prepared a draft order for the removal of the second applicant from the waiting list of persons eligible for social housing.
II.  RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW
Federal Law of 19 February 1993 on Forced Migrants, as worded at the material time
36.  Section 5 of the law set out the procedure for deciding whether a person could be recognised as a forced migrant. Section 5(4) provided, in particular, that the status of forced migrant would be granted for a term of five years. Federal executive authorities, executive authorities responsible for subjects of the Russian Federation, and local government bodies had to take, within the scope of their jurisdiction, the measures set out in section 7 of the law to provide the forced migrant and his or her family members with a new address in the Russian Federation. In the event of circumstances preventing the forced migrant from taking up residence at the new address, the term of validity of his or her status had to be extended by the relevant migration service each subsequent year at the request of the forced migrant.

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, 1.\u00a0\u00a0Declares the complaint concerning the applicants\u2019 right to respect of their home admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;

The case originated in an application (no. 47056/11) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by two Russian nationals, Ms Marina Stanislavovna Panyushkina ("the first applicant") and Mr Vyacheslav Aleksandrovich Panyushkin ("the second applicant"), on 20 May 2011.
events.event_who: The first applicant, the second applicant

events.source_text: The applicants were represented by Ms O.P. Tseytlina, a lawyer practising in St Petersburg.

The Russian Government ("the Government") were represented initially by Mr G. Matyushkin, the Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights, and then by his successor in that office, Mr M. Galperin.
events.event: The Russian Government had legal representation
events.event_who: Mr G. Matyushkin, Mr M. Galperin

events.source_text: The applicants alleged that their right to respect for their home had been violated.
events.event: The applicants claimed a violation of their right to respect for their home

events.source_text: On 19 September 2016 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicants’ right to respect for their home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: The complaint was communicated to the Government

events.source_text: In 1995 the first applicant and her mother left Uzbekistan for Russia and settled in St Petersburg.
events.event: The first applicant and her mother moved to Russia

events.source_text: In 1998 the Federal Migration Service ("the FMS") provided the applicants and the first applicant’s mother with a room in a three-room flat.
events.event: The FMS provided the applicants with a room

events.source_text: In October 2000 the FMS extended the forced migrant status of the first applicant and her mother until 2 June 2001.
events.event: The FMS extended the forced migrant status

events.source_text: In July 2001 the second applicant was registered as living in the room.
events.event: The second applicant was registered as living in the room

events.source_text: On 8 November 2001 the FMS deprived the first applicant of her status as a forced migrant on the grounds that she had not applied in due time for it to be extended.
events.event: The FMS deprived the first applicant of her forced migrant status

events.source_text: In 2002 the first applicant was excluded from the social tenancy agreement owing to the fact that she had lost her forced migrant status.
events.event: The first applicant was excluded from the social tenancy agreement

events.source_text: On 17 February and 16 April 2003 the first applicant applied to the FMS with a request to re-establish her status as a forced migrant.
events.event: The first applicant requested to re-establish her forced migrant status

events.source_text: On 20 February and 8 May 2003 respectively the FMS upheld its decision of 8 November 2001 and dismissed the first applicant’s request.
events.event: The FMS upheld its decision and dismissed the first applicant's request

events.source_text: In February 2009 the first applicant’s mother died.
In July 2009 the FMS ordered the applicants to vacate the room.
events.event: The FMS ordered the applicants to vacate the room

events.source_text: In December 2009 the applicants were placed on the waiting list for social housing.
events.event: The applicants were placed on the waiting list for social housing

events.source_text: On 19 January 2010 the applicant applied to the FMS with a new request to re-establish her forced migrant status.
events.event: The applicant requested to re-establish her forced migrant status

events.source_text: On 25 January 2010 the FMS upheld its decision of 8 November 2001.
events.event: The FMS upheld its decision of 8 November 2001

events.source_text: The first applicant decided to challenge that decision in court.
events.event: The first applicant decided to challenge the decision in court

events.source_text: On 3 November 2010 the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg held that the decision of 25 January 2010 had been unlawful and had to be set aside.
events.event: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg ruled that the FMS's decision was unlawful
events.event_who: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg

events.source_text: In particular, the court held that the first applicant had had valid reasons for missing the deadline for applying for an extension of her forced migrant status.
events.event: The court held that the first applicant had valid reasons for missing the deadline
events.event_who: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg

events.source_text: The court ordered the FMS to extend the first applicant’s migrant status.
events.event: The court ordered the FMS to extend the first applicant's migrant status
events.event_who: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg

events.source_text: On 25 January 2011 the St Petersburg City Court quashed the decision of 3 November 2010 and dismissed the first applicant’s complaint against the decision of the FMS of 25 January 2010.
events.event: The St Petersburg City Court quashed the decision of 3 November 2010

events.source_text: In particular, the court held that between 2003 and 2010 the first applicant had not tried to contest the refusals of the FMS of 8 November 2001, 20 February and 8 May 2003 to re-establish her forced migrant status.
events.event: The court held that the first applicant did not contest the refusals between 2003 and 2010

events.source_text: The court held, in particular, that there were no grounds for declaring that decision unlawful.
events.event: The court held that there were no grounds for declaring the decision unlawful

events.source_text: C.  Eviction proceedings
In 2011 the FMS brought court proceedings against the applicants, seeking their eviction from the room.
events.event: The FMS brought court proceedings against the applicants

events.source_text: The local authorities objected to the eviction, because the room was the only dwelling available to the second applicant.
events.event: The local authorities objected to the eviction

events.source_text: The applicants submitted that their eviction would be in breach of Article 8 of the Convention, since it was not necessary in a democratic society.
events.event: The applicants claimed that their eviction would breach Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: The room in question was their only dwelling.
events.event: The room was the applicants' only dwelling

events.source_text: They had been on the waiting list for social housing since 2009.
events.event: The applicants had been on the waiting list for social housing since 2009

events.source_text: The first applicant was a single mother whose income was insufficient for buying a flat.
events.event: The first applicant's income was insufficient for buying a flat

events.source_text: On 15 May 2012 the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg ordered the applicants’ eviction from their room, without providing any alternative accommodation.
events.event: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg ordered the applicants' eviction
events.event_who: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg

events.source_text: In particular, the District Court held as follows:
events.event: The District Court made a statement
events.event_who: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg

events.source_text: “... Panyushkina M.S. [the first applicant] lost her forced migrant status in 2001, her minor son has never had such a status, and therefore the court comes to the conclusion that the respondents unlawfully occupy the disputed housing and should be evicted without the provision of any alternative accommodation ...”
events.event: The District Court concluded that the applicants unlawfully occupied the room
events.event_who: The Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg

events.source_text: The applicants lodged an appeal against the eviction order, submitting that their eviction was disproportionate since the court had not taken their arguments into account.
events.event: The applicants lodged an appeal against the eviction order

events.source_text: On 4 October 2012 the St Petersburg City Court upheld the eviction order.
events.event: The St Petersburg City Court upheld the eviction order

events.source_text: In particular, the City Court held as follows:
events.event: The City Court made a statement

events.source_text: “... It is impossible to take into account the arguments submitted by Panyushkina M.S. [the first applicant] in her grounds of appeal, whereby the eviction from the disputed housing without the provision of any alternative accommodation is a violation of their [the applicants’] housing rights, since they do not have any other housing. The housing stock aimed at providing forced migrants with temporary housing is for a strictly designated use – the provision with housing of individuals who have been legally acknowledged to be forced migrants and their family members; the loss or deprivation of the status of forced migrant implies the loss of the right to live in the housing, termination of the social tenancy agreement and the obligation to vacate the occupied accommodation ...”
events.event: The City Court made a statement regarding the applicants' housing rights

events.source_text: The applicants did not lodge a cassation appeal against the above decisions.
events.event: The applicants did not lodge a cassation appeal

events.source_text: On 22 November 2012 the bailiff instituted enforcement proceedings with regard to the eviction order.
The applicants were given five days to comply voluntarily with the judgment of 15 May 2012.
events.event: The applicants were given five days to comply voluntarily

events.source_text: D.  Provision of alternative accommodation
events.event: The provision of alternative accommodation was discussed

events.source_text: On 13 May 2013 the first applicant asked the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg to provide her with alternative accommodation.
events.event: The first applicant requested alternative accommodation

events.source_text: On 12 August 2013 the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg concluded an agreement with the first applicant for use of social accommodation free of charge for a period of one year.
events.event: The administration concluded an agreement with the first applicant

events.source_text: The Government submitted that it had been open to the applicants to apply for an extension of that agreement.
events.event: The Government stated that the applicants could have applied for an extension

events.source_text: However, they had not asked for the agreement to be extended after the expiry of the initial period.
events.event: The applicants did not ask for an extension of the agreement

events.source_text: The applicants submitted that it had not been possible to ask for any extension of the agreement.
events.event: The applicants stated that it was not possible to ask for an extension

events.source_text: On 12 September 2013 the applicants vacated the disputed room in compliance with the eviction order of 15 May 2012.
events.event: The applicants vacated the disputed room

events.source_text: On 11 March 2015 the enforcement proceedings were terminated on the grounds that the applicants had voluntarily vacated the room.
Since 15 March 2016 the second applicant has been registered as living in the flat belonging to his father and his paternal grandmother.
events.event: The second applicant was registered as living in a flat

events.source_text: The first applicant was currently renting for her and her son a room in a shared apartment at her own expense.
events.event: The first applicant was renting a room

events.source_text: Her landlord had not registered her as living at the address of the rented room.
events.event: The landlord did not register the first applicant's residence

events.source_text: She submitted that she had asked her former husband to register the second applicant as living in his flat by necessity, because the absence of registration had subjected him to everyday difficulties.
events.event: The first applicant requested her former husband to register the second applicant

events.source_text: However, de facto the second applicant had continued to live with the first applicant.
events.event: The second applicant continued to live with the first applicant

events.source_text: According to the information provided by the Government, in 2016 the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg prepared a draft order for the removal of the second applicant from the waiting list of persons eligible for social housing.
events.event: The Government provided information about a draft order

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event: The Court made a unanimous decision

events.source_text: 1.   Declares the complaint concerning the applicants’ right to respect of their home admissible and the remainder of the application inadmissible;
events.event: The Court declared the complaint admissible and the remainder inadmissible

events.source_text: 2.   Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: The Court held that there was a violation of Article 8 of the Convention

events.source_text: 3.   Holds (a)  that the respondent State is to pay the two applicants jointly, within three months of the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, EUR 7,500 (seven thousand five hundred euros), plus any tax that may be chargeable, in respect of non-pecuniary damage, to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement;
events.event: The Court held that the respondent state is to pay compensation

events.source_text: (b)  that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: The Court held that simple interest will be payable

events.source_text: 4.   Dismisses the remainder of the applicants’ claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: The Court dismissed the remainder of the applicants' claim

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 21 November 2017, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: The judgment was made and notified

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 47056/11) against the Russian Federation lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by two Russian nationals, Ms Marina Stanislavovna Panyushkina (“the first applicant”) and Mr Vyacheslav Aleksandrovich Panyushkin (“the second applicant”), on 20 May 2011.
The applicants were represented by Ms O.P. Tseytlina, a lawyer practising in St Petersburg.

The Russian Government (“the Government”) were represented initially by Mr G. Matyushkin, the Representative of the Russian Federation to the European Court of Human Rights, and then by his successor in that office, Mr M. Galperin.

On 19 September 2016 the complaint concerning the alleged violation of the applicants’ right to respect for their home was communicated to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 × 3 of the Rules of Court.
The applicants were born in 1971 and 1997 respectively and live in St Petersburg. They are a single mother and her son.

In 1995 the first applicant and her mother left Uzbekistan for Russia and settled in St Petersburg. They were granted the status of “forced migrants” for an initial period of five years. In 1997 the second applicant was born.

In 1998 the Federal Migration Service (“the FMS”) provided the applicants and the first applicant's mother with a room in a three-room flat. A social tenancy agreement was concluded with the first applicant's mother.
events.event_who: Federal Migration Service, applicants, first applicant's mother

events.source_text: In October 2000 the FMS extended the forced migrant status of the first applicant and her mother until 2 June 2001.
In July 2001 the second applicant was registered as living in the room.

On 8 November 2001 the FMS deprived the first applicant of her status as a forced migrant on the grounds that she had not applied in due time for it to be extended. According to the first applicant, she was not informed of that decision until 2003.
In 2002 the first applicant was excluded from the social tenancy agreement owing to the fact that she had lost her forced migrant status.
On 17 February and 16 April 2003 the first applicant applied to the FMS with a request to re-establish her status as a forced migrant.
events.event_what: applied to re-establish forced migrant status

events.source_text: On 20 February and 8 May 2003 respectively the FMS upheld its decision of 8 November 2001 and dismissed the first applicant's request.
In February 2009 the first applicant's mother died.
In July 2009 the FMS ordered the applicants to vacate the room. The applicants did not vacate the room and continued to live in it.
In December 2009 the applicants were placed on the waiting list for social housing.
On 19 January 2010 the applicant applied to the FMS with a new request to re-establish her forced migrant status.
events.event_what: applied to re-establish forced migrant status

events.source_text: On 25 January 2010 the FMS upheld its decision of 8 November 2001.
The first applicant decided to challenge that decision in court.

On 3 November 2010 the Primorskiy District Court of St Petersburg held that the decision of 25 January 2010 had been unlawful and had to be set aside. In particular, the court held that the first applicant had had valid reasons for missing the deadline for applying for an extension of her forced migrant status. The court ordered the FMS to extend the first applicant's migrant status.
On 25 January 2011 the St Petersburg City Court quashed the decision of 3 November 2010 and dismissed the first applicant's complaint against the decision of the FMS of 25 January 2010.
The applicants did not lodge a cassation appeal against the above decisions.
On 22 November 2012 the bailiff instituted enforcement proceedings with regard to the eviction order.
The applicants did not lodge a cassation appeal against the above decisions.
On 13 May 2013 the first applicant asked the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg to provide her with alternative accommodation.

On 12 August 2013 the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg concluded an agreement with the first applicant for use of social accommodation free of charge for a period of one year.
On 12 September 2013 the applicants vacated the disputed room in compliance with the eviction order of 15 May 2012.
On 11 March 2015 the enforcement proceedings were terminated on the grounds that the applicants had voluntarily vacated the room.
Since 15 March 2016 the second applicant has been registered as living in the flat belonging to his father and his paternal grandmother.
The first applicant was currently renting for her and her son a room in a shared apartment at her own expense. Her landlord had not registered her as living at the address of the rented room.

She submitted that she had asked her former husband to register the second applicant as living in his flat by necessity, because the absence of registration had subjected him to everyday difficulties. However, de facto the second applicant had continued to live with the first applicant.

According to the information provided by the Government, in 2016 the administration of the Primorskiy District of St Petersburg prepared a draft order for the removal of the second applicant from the waiting list of persons eligible for social housing.
